mnemonic: EU sounds like 'AY-OO' - Hey YOU! No wait I mean ME!
grammar_notes: Subject pronoun - often omitted when verb conjugation makes subject clear
cultural_note: Portuguese drops pronouns because verb endings indicate subject
tip: Practice saying 'Eu sou...' (I am...) to introduce yourself

mnemonic: TU = like saying 'TOO' - me too I'm talking to YOU!
grammar_notes: Informal 'you' for friends/family - uses 2nd person verb conjugation
cultural_note: In Portugal 'tu' is common casually - Lisbon uses it a lot!
tip: Use 'tu' only when you're sure the relationship is informal

grammar_notes: Formal 'you' that uses 3rd person verb conjugation (like ele/ela)
cultural_note: More common in Brazil - in Portugal used for respect/professional
tip: When unsure use 'você' - it's safer in professional situations

mnemonic: ELE = 'EL-eh' - sounds like 'elephant' he's an elephant!
grammar_notes: Masculine 3rd person singular - for male people and masculine nouns
cultural_note: Portuguese nouns have gender so objects can be 'ele' if masculine
tip: Remember: ele = he (ends in E) / ela = she (ends in A)

mnemonic: ELA = 'EL-ah' - ELA ends in A for girl/gal!
grammar_notes: Feminine 3rd person singular - for female people and feminine nouns
cultural_note: Many Portuguese words ending in -a are feminine
tip: Notice how ela ends in -a matching feminine noun patterns

mnemonic: NÓS sounds like 'KNOWS' - we all KNOW together!
grammar_notes: 1st person plural - accent shows stress. Informal alternative: 'a gente'
cultural_note: In casual speech 'a gente' is very common instead of 'nós'
tip: Informal: 'A gente fala português' = 'Nós falamos português'

mnemonic: VOCÊS = multiple VOCÊs - you and you and you!
grammar_notes: Plural 'you' - addressing multiple people - uses 3rd person plural verbs
cultural_note: Used for any group you're addressing directly
tip: Use when talking to more than one person

mnemonic: ELES = 'EL-ush' - like ELE but with S for plural!
grammar_notes: Used for all-male groups OR mixed groups (even 1 male = eles)
cultural_note: Portuguese rule: masculine for mixed groups (common in romance languages)
tip: Mixed group = masculine plural - standard Portuguese grammar

mnemonic: ELAS = 'EL-ahsh' - ELA with S for female plural!
grammar_notes: Used ONLY for all-female groups - one male switches to 'eles'
cultural_note: Use only when the entire group is female
tip: Remember: elas = ALL female / eles = any males present

mnemonic: A GENTE = 'the people' - we the people (informal we)
grammar_notes: Very common informal 'we' - takes 3rd person SINGULAR verb!
cultural_note: Extremely common in everyday speech - more casual than 'nós'
tip: Warning: A gente + singular verb! (A gente vai NOT A gente vamos)
